Arteriovenous Malformation (AVM)_1:
Description 1:
    A 32-year-old female patient, with no significant medical history, presents with a complex set of symptoms. She has been experiencing severe, throbbing headaches (rated 8/10 on the pain scale) for the past six months, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Additionally, the patient reports a progressive loss of neurological function, including episodes of seizures and weakness in her left arm. Neurological examination revealed a noticeable paralysis in the affected limb. These symptoms have had a detrimental impact on her daily life and ability to work. The patient has also noticed swollen veins on her scalp. Despite previous treatments for migraines, her symptoms persist, prompting further investigation.
Arteriovenous Malformation (AVM)_2:
Description 2:
    A 45-year-old male patient, known for his active lifestyle, has recently encountered a concerning health issue. He described persistent, intense headaches (rated 7/10 on the pain scale) over the last four months, often associated with episodes of nausea and vomiting. The patient, who has a history of occasional seizures, reported an increase in their frequency and duration. He has also noticed a progressive weakness in his right leg, leading to occasional stumbling and loss of coordination. These neurological symptoms have raised significant concerns for the patient, affecting his mobility and ability to engage in physical activities. Despite his efforts to manage the headaches with over-the-counter medications, the symptoms persist, prompting a thorough medical evaluation.
Arteriovenous Malformation (AVM)_3:
Description 3:
    A 7-year-old male child is brought in by his parents due to a worrisome health presentation. The parents reported that the child has been experiencing recurrent headaches (rated 6/10 on the pain scale) and episodes of nausea and vomiting. Of particular concern are the changes in the child's behavior and learning abilities, as observed by his teachers at school. The parents noted that he has become increasingly irritable and demonstrates trouble with memory and concentration. Neurological examination revealed a subtle weakness in the child's left arm, along with a tendency to favor his right side. Additionally, there is an unusual enlargement of the child's head, not consistent with normal growth. These symptoms have led to a decline in the child's academic performance and overall behavior, prompting a comprehensive medical assessment.
